data.text:
AT THE HELM

JOHN ASH SAT DOWN WITH HISTORIAN JAMES HOLLAND FOR A CHAT ABOUT BRITISH GENERAL BERNARD MONTGOMERY, HOW HE FOUGHT AND LED IN NORMANDY AND, OF COURSE, ABOUT HIS LEGENDARY WARTIME REPUTATION.

Q : As an introduction, what was Montgomery’s role in Normandy and what were his plans and objectives?

A: Montgomery was promoted from Eighth Army commander in Italy to overall Allied ground commander for Operation Overlord, the Allied invasion of Normandy.

Under him was British Second Army, US First Army and Canadian Second Army. Once much of Normandy had been captured, General George Patton would land with US Third Army and at that point, Monty was to relinquish overall control as General Omar Bradley took over the newly activated US 12th Army Group. Monty was to take command of 21st Army Group, which included British, Canadian and Polish forces.

He was overall in charge of preparing plans for the landings and development of a bridgehead. He took over in early January 1944 and immediately oversaw the expansion of earlier invasion plans, although this was done in consultation with his peers and superiors.
